709429f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Avenue - 34th Street (East)
709429f-a.text:
Second Ave., north from East 34th Street. Intersection in the fore-
ground is East 35th Street. On the right, north of that point appears a
row of buildings that were included in the demolition for St. Gabriels
Park.
About 1891.

707823f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707823f-a.text:
3iAI. AI 320NO NWNe 34th 3.2, NRRIL 1302
Showing the Second Avenue Elevated Railroad (Metropolitan
:1evated Railway Company), and the joint station of the Second
Avenue "V' E the 34th Street Spur (Third Avenue Line) at
Second Avenue E 34th Street. Looking north. Ihe sur structures
were taken possession of by the City of New York, July 15, 1330,
and removed.

707830f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707830f-a.text:
Second Avenue, north from East 35th Street
as viewed from the extreSity of the Downtown Station
at 34th Street of the Second Avenue "El".
To the right is St. Gabriel's Park, the white
building housing the New York Public Library branch
of that name, the Hall structure, and the Church proper
on 37th Street. All of these will be gone in early 1940
as this entire block will be cleared for the plaza approach
to the Oueens-Midtown Tunnel. Note in the background the
group of apartment buildings forming Tudor City. Cl se
observation will distinguish the fact of almost completion
of same. Subsequently other units will be erected and
the skyline changed, thereby obliterating a view of the
long roofed Hospital for Huptured and Crippled Children.
This appears in the due center of this photo.
February 5, 1928
P. L. Sperr

730239f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue (Northwest).]
730239f-a.text:
A meneral view northwestsard from tNe "Eg" platform at
E. 54th Street and Second Avenue, towards the Midtown-42nd Street
district. Note the absence of the tall structures that will rise
in the ensueing year. Close to the right margin is the Commodore
Hotel xith the Graybar Building above same. Both are on Lexington
Svenue, north of 42nd Street. A later view will find these
obstructed by the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings.
February 5, 1928.
.L. Sperr

712110f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712110f-a.text:
East 34th Street, West from Second Avenue (foreground, not seen)
showing the spur that connects the Second and Third elevated lines at
this point. The photographer is viewing westward from atop No. 321
East 34th Street, a building between First and Second Avenues. Note
the absence of the Empire State Bldg.
September 16, 1929.
P. L. Sperr

712116f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street - 2nd Avenue
712116f-a.text:
34th Street, north side, west from No. 305 East, east of Second
Avenue, showing the double Elevated station at the junction of
the regular Second Avenue line and the 34th Street spur; the
latter is shortly to go out of use.
March 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

712109f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street - 2nd Avenue
712109f-a.text:
34th Street, west from and including SecondAvenue. This shows
the elevated structure running from Third ..vOnue to the East River.
At the time this branch was built the law stated that all elevated
lines must connect with railroads or ferries. It was on this
branch that electricity was first used for experimentation, pre-
paratory to electrifying all the lines. The structure is about
to be torn down.
The picture shows a fine view of the Empire State Building.
June 25, 1931.
International News.

712111f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street - 2nd Avenue
712111f-a.text:
3dth Street, north side, west from and including Second Aven
showing the double Elevated station st Second Avenue ard 3
Street. Service has been ciscontinued on the 34th Street
and the elevated structure taken down east of Second Avenu
September 11, 1931.
L. SpeIsr.

712118f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712118f-a.text:
243 East 34th Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Second Ave.
Shown is the Greek Orthodox Church of St. John the Baptist, Rr:  2, . CS
Ce.0
October 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

712122f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712122f-a.text:
222 to 246 East 34th Street, south side, east from a point midway
between Third and Second Aves., and to the latter, showing in the fore-
ground four 4-story tenements (Nos. 222 to 228 inclusive) that will be
demolished and upon whose site will rise a 9-story modern,part glass,
apartment house. For an account of same, see, the New York Times of
January 23, 1938.
January 30, 1938.
George D. Chinn.

712125f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712125f-a.text:
Rast 34th Street, north side, west from Second to Third
Avenues. No. 221-29 is U. S. Post Office Station "F" and was
the former Borden Co. plant site. To the right is the generating
plant of the Manhattan Railroad Co. (Station No. 6) that hooked
up to the spur line on this thoroughfare.
October 16, 1938
Ueorge D. Chinn

707825f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707825f-a.text:
Second Avenue, west side, north from E. 34th to 35th Streets.
January 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707826f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707826f-a.text:
Second Avenue, west side, south from E. 35th to 34th
Streets. Note the "El" station at the latter point.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707827f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707827f-a.text:
Second Avenue, east side, south from E. 35th to 34th Streets,
showing a row of old tenements occupying this frontage. Note the
34th Street "El" station at the right and its high double platform.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707828f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707828f-a.text:
Second Avenue, east side, north from E. 34th to 35th
Streets . North of the latter point,(at the left) appears
St. Gabriel's Park and the Public Library of the sme name.
January 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707837f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707837f-a.text:
Second Avenue, west side, south from E. 36th Street.
Note the "El" station at 34th Street.
January 6, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York Gity Tunnel Authority

707838f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - 34th St. E.
707838f-a.text:
Second Avcnue, east side, south from E. 36th Street, showing
the westerly half of St. Gabriel's Park. Across same and facing
the park is Golumbia University's Institute of Public Adminstration.
This building formerly housed said institutions Gollege of
Dental and Oral Surgery. The large loft structure is the Harriet
Hubbard Ayer building No. 317-323 E. 34th Street.
January 6, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Autnority

712093f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712093f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, seuth side, east frem Secend Avenue te
the East River.
Vanuary 7, 1939

New Yerk City Tunnel Autherity

712094f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712094f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, north side, east from Second Avenue to the
East River. Overhead is the Second Avenue'El" and its 34th Street
Station. Nete at the right the T beams to which were hooked the
34th Street spur line that formerly ran to the Borden Avenue Ferry
terminal at the waters edge. To the center of this view and slightly
east of the corner is the 4 story building housing Coldmbia University's
College of Dental and Oral Surgery. Adjoining same is the 12 story
Harriet Hubbard Ayer Building (No. 317-323 E. 34th Street.)
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712096f-b.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712096f-b.text:
East 34th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W.
oorner of Second Avenue (extreme right, not shown), as
photographed in a northeastward direction. On the left
margin appears a portion of the new Post Office Station F.
Views 2 &: 3 detail the 3 story stable at No. 235 and the
adjacent generating plant at No 237.
May 26, 1939
No's. 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr

712096f-c.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712096f-c.text:
East 34th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W.
oorner of Second Avenue (extreme right, not shown), as
photographed in a northeastward direction. On the left

712096f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712096f-a.text:

oorner of Second Avenue (extreme right, not shown), as

712108f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712108f-a.text:
East 34th Street, at Second Avenue, as photographed from
the Harriet Hubbard Ayer Bldg., showing prominently the
Second Avenue "El" station. The buildings included are
on the south side of 34th Street, being east and west of
the Avenue. The photographer is viewing southwestward.
October 13, 1939
P. L. Sperr

712114f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712114f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, north side, west of Second Avenue, showing
prominently the block extending between Second and Third Avenues.
In the center of sime is a 3 story structure housing U. S. Post
Cffice Station "F". This site is proposed as the future entrance
to the Midtown Queens Tunnel under the East River. It has only been
possible in the last year to take such a photo since the spur line
connecting the two "El' lines was demolished (Surmmer 1938). The
link that extended to the East River came down in 1930.
January 7, 1939
Son.ach Photo Service
Ne~ York Wity Tunnel Authority
LINE AUTROR ITY  IT

712126f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712126f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, south sce, west from Second to Third
AVenues, showing a row of structures that will remain and face
the entrance to the 38th Street tunnel under the East Tiver. On
the two Avenues nentioned appear tneir respective "El" lines and
34th Street stations. Srevious to the Summer of 1938 these were
joined by a spur line, a remnant ef a link with the Ferry to
Borcen Avenue. Early legislatien neccessitated same, stating that
all transportation facilities join up with either railroad terminals
or water facilities. The writer believes the drug store appearing
on the left to be place of business from which Col. C'Brien emanated
and was fatally attacked during the Draft Riots of 18o3. For
accounts of same, see "Gangs cf New York" by H. Asbury and "Boss
Tweed" by Dennis Lynch etc.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

Views 1, to 3;
East 34th Street, from Second Avenue elevated

712098f-b.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
712098f-b.text:
Eaat 34th Street, north side, east of Second Avenue,
showing the by-pass roadway leading to the Midtown-
Cueens Tunnel under construction. This will run thru
the 34th -35th Street block and into St. Gabriels Park.
View 1 shows the Columbia University building at 310
bein; demolished. View 2 is the same site later showing
the swath necessarg. Note the library building on 36th
Street still standing. View 3 is limited to the road
bed thru the Park.
1: October 11, 1939
2S3: April 11, 19440
P. L. Sperr

712106f-b.text:

this crosstown thoroughfare before end after the re-
moval of the remaining portion of the spur line bet-
ween the Second and Third Avenue'e "E1" lines. This
section was allowed to remain in a stripped condition
because of the power supply house at the right margin.
In the left background appear the blending 71st Regi-
mcnt Armory tower and the Vanderbilt Hotel, overshad-
owed by the dominant Empire State Bldg.

23: May 27, 1939
